Why Fine-Tuning Struggles with Forgetting in Machine Unlearning? Theoretical Insights and a Remedial Approach

Meng Ding, Jinhui Xu & Kaiyi Ji
Department of Computer Science and Engineering
State University of New York at Buffalo
{mengding,jinhui,kaiyiji}@buffalo.edu
Abstract

Machine Unlearning has emerged as a significant area of research, focusing on ‚Äôremoving‚Äô specific subsets of data from a trained model. Fine-tuning (FT) methods have become one of the fundamental approaches for approximating unlearning, as they effectively retain model performance. However, it is consistently observed that naive FT methods struggle to forget the targeted data. In this paper, we present the first theoretical analysis of FT methods for machine unlearning within a linear regression framework, providing a deeper exploration of this phenomenon. We investigate two scenarios with distinct features and overlapping features. Our findings reveal that FT models can achieve zero remaining loss yet fail to forget the forgetting data, unlike golden models (trained from scratch without the forgetting data). This analysis reveals that naive FT methods struggle with forgetting because the pretrained model retains information about the forgetting data, and the fine-tuning process has no impact on this retained information. To address this issue, we first propose a theoretical approach to mitigate the retention of forgetting data in the pretrained model. Our analysis shows that removing the forgetting data‚Äôs influence allows FT models to match the performance of the golden model. Building on this insight, we introduce a discriminative regularization term to practically reduce the unlearning loss gap between the fine-tuned model and the golden model. Our experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets validate these theoretical insights and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed regularization method.

1 Introduction

Machine Unlearning has emerged as a prominent area that focuses on protecting individual privacy during the model training process, particularly adhering to legislation such as ‚Äôthe right to be forgotten‚Äô [22] under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) [13]. That is, it removes certain training samples from the trained model upon their users‚Äô data deletion request. A natural approach to machine unlearning is to retrain the model from scratch, excluding the data that needs to be forgotten; this is known as exact unlearning. However, this method is highly computationally inefficient. To address this challenge, previous research has proposed a more relaxed definition of machine unlearning, where the unlearned model only needs to be approximately similar to one retrained from scratch. This led to the development of approximate unlearning methods, such as Fine-Tuning [30, 8], Gradient Ascent [10, 28], Fisher Forgetting [1, 8], and Influence Unlearning[14].

Fine-tuning, as one of the most widely used approaches in approximate unlearning, has demonstrated its empirical effectiveness. However, it can be observed in many studies [16, 30, 8, 17, 24] and our investigations in Table¬†1 that while fine-tuning may maintain the utility of the model on remaining data, it struggles to forget the targeted data. This raises a natural question:

Why does fine-tuning fail to unlearn the forgetting data in machine unlearning?

To answer this question, we revisit the machine unlearning problem with a simple yet fundamental over-parameterized linear regression model and explore the behavior of fine-tuning through a theoretical perspective.

Our main contributions can be summarized as follows.

  • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

    Theoretical Analysis: Distinct and Overlapping Features. We provide the first theoretical analysis of FT methods in the context of machine unlearning within a linear regression framework. Specifically, ùüè)\mathbf{1)}bold_1 ) Based on the assumption of distinct features (1), our theoretical observations, which align with empirical studies, show that the remaining loss for the fine-tuning model is zero, matching that of the golden model. Moreover, the loss of the fine-tuning model on the forgetting dataset consistently remains zero, diverging from the performance of the golden model. ùüê)\mathbf{2)}bold_2 ) we extend our analysis to a more complex case when the dataset retained for model retraining shares overlapping features with the forgetting dataset. This challenges assumptions of distinct feature sets across datasets, yet the previous conclusions remain valid in this case. More discussion refers to Section¬†3.

  • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

    Theory for Enhanced Unlearning. Our analysis shows that naive fine-tuning (FT) methods fail to unlearn the forgetting data because the pretrained model retains information about this data, and the fine-tuning process does not effectively alter that retention. To address this issue, we propose a theoretical approach that removes the influence of the forgetting data, mitigating its retention in the pretrained model. This enables FT models to significantly improve unlearning accuracy while preserving the accuracy on the remaining data. Furthermore, our findings provide key insights for designing machine unlearning algorithms: retaining overlapping features between the remaining and forgetting datasets has minimal impact on unlearning accuracy, while discarding these features results in a decrease in the accuracy on the remaining data.

  • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

    From Theory to Algorithm: Discriminative Regularization. Building on the aforementioned analysis, we introduce a discriminative regularization term to practically reduce the unlearning loss gap between the fine-tuned model and the golden model. Specifically, in addition to the standard loss function for optimizing performance on the remaining data, we introduce an additional loss function specifically targeting the forgetting data. This loss encourages the model to learn incorrect labels for the targeted data and will be regulated by a tunable regularization parameter during the fine-tuning process, allowing for a controlled trade-off between unlearning and remaining accuracy.

  • ‚àô‚àô\bullet‚àô

    Experimental Validation on Synthetic and Real-World Data. We validate our theoretical findings on both synthetic and real-world datasets. Firstly, our experiments demonstrate that all regularization-based methods significantly improve UA compared to the baseline FT. Furthermore, we observe that in the fine-tuning process, focusing on preserving accuracy on remaining data along with regularization on forgetting data to enhance unlearning achieves both good RA and UA. However, placing more emphasis on using the forgetting data to improve UA can significantly degrade RA, consistent with our analysis.

1.1 Related Work

Machine Unlearning Methods. [2] first defined "Unlearning" as the removal of a sample that produces the same output on the dataset as if the sample had never been trained. The natural way to solve the problem is to retrain a model from scratch in response to each data deletion request. However, retraining is not feasible due to the limited time and constrained resources. [7] provided a relaxed definition inspired by Differential Privacy [5], which only requires the unlearned model to produce results similar to those of retrain-from-scratch models. This led to the development of "approximate unlearning" methods, offering more efficient computational designs for machine unlearning. [11, 14, 19, 29, 23] provide theoretical error guarantees by focusing on the empirical risk minimization problem under this probabilistic notion of unlearning. [8] proposed an information-based procedure to remove knowledge from the trained weights, without access to the original training data. Further, [9] approximated the weights inspired by NTK theory, addressing situations where the Hessian is not informative about where the model will converge into a null space. [18] avoid the computation of Hessian by introducing a method only computing conditional independence, which identifies the Markov Blanket of parameters requiring updates. [28] proposed a regularizer to reduce the ‚Äòverification error,‚Äô which represents the distance between the unlearned model and a retrained-from-scratch model. [16] bears a novel teacher-student formulation to achieve better performance towards unbounded unlearning problems. [17] considers model sparsity by pruning weights before the unlearning process, thereby introducing a new unlearning paradigm. [25] incorporates the variational inference and contrastive learning approaches to address the lack of supervision information (label-agnostic).

Machine Unlearning Theory. For approximate unlearning, [19, 28] explored algorithms for empirical risk minimization objectives, while [23] studied population risk minimization problems, providing theoretical guarantees on both the effectiveness of unlearning and the privacy of the data subjects. [11, 32] provided the certified radius with respect to data changes before and after removals, as well as the certified budget for data removals. For exact unlearning, [29] introduced the notion of algorithmic stability, called Total Variation (TV) stability, which is suited for achieving exact unlearning. This concept was further extended to the federated setting by [3, 27]. However, existing theoretical work has primarily focused on utility guarantees, with limited analysis explaining the successes and failures of fine-tuning methods.

Learning Procedure We consider the machine unlearning problem based on the fine-tuning method dividing the learning process into two distinct phases: Original Training and Fine-tuning (Unlearning). Our goal is to evaluate how the fine-tuning solution ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT differs from the golden model solution ùê∞gsubscriptùê∞ùëî\mathbf{w}_{g}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which refers to retraining the model parameters from scratch over the remaining dataset Drsubscriptùê∑ùëüD_{r}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Existing work has assessed machine unlearning performance from various perspectives [10, 1, 8, 26]. In this paper, we focus particularly on the Unlearning accuracy (UA) and Remaining accuracy (RA), which refers to the model performance on the forgetting and remaining dataset respectively.

3 Naive Fine-Tuning Methods Fail to Unlearn

In empirical studies [16, 30, 8] and Table¬†1, it can be observed that fine-tuning may retain the utility of a model but struggles to forget. In this section, we revisit this phenomenon, aiming to explain why the vanilla fine-tuning method succeeds in retaining the model‚Äôs utility on the remaining dataset but fails to forget the targeted data it was trained on.

3.1 Distinct Features

To simplify our analysis, we first consider distinct features with the following assumption:

Assumption 1.

The datasets ùêófsubscriptùêóùëì\mathbf{X}_{f}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùêórsubscriptùêóùëü\mathbf{X}_{r}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT possess distinct non-zero features, while ùê∞‚àósubscriptùê∞\mathbf{w}_{*}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT embodies the coefficients applicable across all features.

In an ideal scenario for classification tasks, each class possesses its own unique set of features that distinctly differentiates it from other classes. Here, ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT refers to the unlearned model via fine-tuning, ùê∞gsubscriptùê∞ùëî\mathbf{w}_{g}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT refers to the model parameter retrained from scratch, RL and UL refer to the remaining loss on the remaining data and the unlearning loss on the forgetting data. Note that higher RL and UL corresponde to lower RA and UA.

Theorem¬†1 presents two interesting observations: 1) The fine-tuning model can perform perfectly on the remaining dataset, which indicates that the information from training data has been preserved from the original model, ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to the unlearned model via fine-tuning, ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. 2) The loss of the fine-tuning model on the forgetting dataset consistently remains zero, which diverges from the performance of the golden model. This suggests that the fine-tuning model is unable to forget the information it previously acquired from ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which may be contradicted by catastrophic forgetting in continual learning [21, 4].

To illustrate the behavior of fine-tuning during the unlearning process more clearly, we consider the projective nature of learning. Firstly, the solution of Equation¬†2 can be represented as

ùê∞t=(ùêà‚àíùêèt)‚Å¢ùê∞o+ùêèt‚Å¢ùê∞‚àór,subscriptùê∞ùë°ùêàsubscriptùêèùë°subscriptùê∞ùëúsubscriptùêèùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëü\mathbf{w}_{t}=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{P}_{t})\mathbf{w}_{o}+\mathbf{P}_{t}\mathbf% {w}_{*}^{r},bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_I - bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (4)

According to the property of projection Corollary¬†1, multiplying any data matrix by a projection matrix preserves the components of the data that lie within the subspace defined by the projection. Moreover, under the distinct features assumption, it holds that

Thus, the unlearned model ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Equation¬†2 decomposed into two components for the unlearning process: the first part, ùê∞‚àórsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëü\mathbf{w}_{*}^{r}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, preserves the accuracy on the remaining data, while the second part, ùê∞‚àófsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì\mathbf{w}_{*}^{f}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, also ensures accuracy on the forget data. However, the projection of ùê∞‚àófsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì\mathbf{w}_{*}^{f}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT onto the fine-tuning space ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has no effect, ultimately resulting in the unlearned model ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being the same as the pretrained model ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3.2 Overlapping Features

In practical scenarios, training datasets often deviate from ideal classifications, introducing complexities such as overlapping features between subsets. This challenges assumptions of distinct feature sets across datasets. Therefore, we extend our previous analysis to address the presence of overlapped features. In the following, we begin by defining overlapped features.

Assumption 2.

The datasets ùêófsubscriptùêóùëì\mathbf{X}_{f}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùêórsubscriptùêóùëü\mathbf{X}_{r}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT possess drsubscriptùëëùëüd_{r}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overlapped features, while ùê∞‚àósubscriptùê∞\mathbf{w}_{*}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT embodies the coefficients applicable across all features.

Theorem 2.

Suppose a model is trained by the procedure 2 and 3 separately. Under the 2, it holds that

Theorem¬†2 shows that the previous conclusions remain valid under the assumptions of overlapping features, as the information from all training data, including forget data, is preserved from the pretrained model, ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to the unlearned model through fine-tuning, ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Consequently, the loss on both the remaining dataset and the forgetting dataset for the fine-tuning model is zero. Additionally, an interesting observation is that the number of overlapping features does not impact the unlearning accuracy of the fine-tuning model.

Both Theorem¬†1 and Theorem¬†2 present similar findings regarding the performance of the unlearned model through fine-tuning. We run a synthetic experiment to validate these results (more experimental details in Appendix¬†A). In Figure¬†1(a) and Figure¬†1(b), both distinct and overlapping feature assumptions demonstrate the same results: 1) The remaining loss of fine-tuning model ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and golden model ùê∞gsubscriptùê∞ùëî\mathbf{w}_{g}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is zero, indicating that the fine-tuning model performs equivalently to the golden model, successfully retaining the model‚Äôs utility on the remaining dataset. 2) The unlearning loss of the fine-tuning model consistently remains at zero, differing from the golden model, suggesting that the fine-tuning model fails to forget the information obtained from the pretrained model. These empirical findings align well with our theoretical analysis.

4 Eliminating Forgetting Data Features from Pre-Trained Model Enhances Unlearning

Compared to the golden model ùê∞g=ùêèr‚Å¢ùê∞‚àórsubscriptùê∞ùëîsubscriptùêèùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëü\mathbf{w}_{g}=\mathbf{P}_{r}\mathbf{w}_{*}^{r}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the unlearned model can be viewed as having an additional second term as

ùê∞t=ùêèùê∞‚àór+(ùêè‚àíùêèt)‚Å¢ùê∞‚àóf.subscriptùê∞ùë°superscriptsubscriptùêèùê∞ùëüùêèsubscriptùêèùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì\mathbf{w}_{t}=\mathbf{P}\mathbf{w}_{*}^{r}+(\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{P}_{t})\mathbf% {w}_{*}^{f}.bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_Pw start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( bold_P - bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

This additional term (ùêè‚àíùêèt)‚Å¢ùê∞‚àófùêèsubscriptùêèùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì(\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{P}_{t})\mathbf{w}_{*}^{f}( bold_P - bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents the residual influence of the data intended to be forgotten on the unlearned model, contributing to the unlearning accuracy (UA) gap between ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the golden model ùê∞gsubscriptùê∞ùëî\mathbf{w}_{g}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A natural approach to mitigate this gap might involve making the fine-tuning space converge toward the pretraining space-that is, aligning ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with ùêèrsubscriptùêèùëü\mathbf{P}_{r}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, this strategy is inefficient and contradictory, as it would lead to the optimal solution for the fine-tuning dataset becoming identical to that of the entire dataset, undermining the purpose and benefits of fine-tuning.

Inspired by the formulation of the unlearned model:

ùê∞t=(ùêà‚àíùêèt)‚Å¢ùê∞o+ùêèt‚Å¢ùê∞‚àór.subscriptùê∞ùë°ùêàsubscriptùêèùë°subscriptùê∞ùëúsubscriptùêèùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëü\mathbf{w}_{t}=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{P}_{t})\mathbf{w}_{o}+\mathbf{P}_{t}\mathbf% {w}_{*}^{r}.bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_I - bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

To mitigate the UA gap between the fine-tuning model and the golden model, it becomes evident that the remaining portion of the pretrained model does not contribute to UA. Specifically, the components of the pretrained model ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated with the forgetting data (ùê∞‚àóf)superscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì(\mathbf{w}_{*}^{f})( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) do not enhance performance on the remaining dataset Drsubscriptùê∑ùëüD_{r}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, if we can eliminate the forgetting component‚Äîspecifically by removing the ùê∞‚àófsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëì\mathbf{w}_{*}^{f}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT term from ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äîthe divergence can be addressed. In the following, we provide a formal description of this modification. Consider the same learning procedure Equation¬†1 to obtain the pretrained model ùê∞osubscriptùê∞ùëú\mathbf{w}_{o}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. According to Theorem¬†3, under the distinct features assumption, the regularized unlearned model achieves the same remaining and unlearning loss as the golden model. Furthermore, when considering overlapping features, if the overlapped component from the pretrained model is retained, the remaining loss remains zero, as with the golden model, while the unlearning loss differs only in the projection component. This difference can be considered negligible when applied to ùê∞‚àórsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëü\mathbf{w}_{*}^{r}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùê∞‚àól‚Å¢a‚Å¢psuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëôùëéùëù\mathbf{w}_{*}^{lap}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l italic_a italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT due to the model assumption. Figure¬†1(c) and Figure¬†1(d) verify our theoretical conclusions. However, if the overlapped component is discarded from the pretrained model, the remaining loss is no longer zero, and there is a small change to the unlearning loss that can be overlooked. These findings offer several insights into the design of machine unlearning algorithms: 1) Regularization on the pretrained model can significantly improve unlearning accuracy while preserving the remaining accuracy. If we can identify the component of the pretrained model related to the forgetting data, applying regularization to this component can further enhance UA. Our theorem also explains recent related works, such as [17, 6], which apply a mask to the pretrained model either randomly or by regularizing the weights associated with the forgetting data to provide better unlearn performance. These methods share the same underlying principle discussed here.

2) When considering overlapping features, retaining them does not substantially affect unlearning accuracy, but discarding them compromises the remaining accuracy. As shown in Theorem¬†3, the remaining loss can not retain zero unless the remaining data ùêórsubscriptùêóùëü\mathbf{X}_{r}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be fully represented by the fine-tuning space, meaning ùêèt‚Å¢ùêór=ùêórsubscriptùêèùë°subscriptùêóùëüsubscriptùêóùëü\mathbf{P}_{t}\mathbf{X}_{r}=\mathbf{X}_{r}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Additionally, as the number of overlapping features increases, the impact on both remaining and unlearning loss becomes more significant. Discarding too many overlapping components can lead to instability in the remaining accuracy, as the model loses essential information needed to represent Drsubscriptùê∑ùëüD_{r}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which in turn causes the remaining loss to increase. Figure¬†1 and Figure¬†2 validate our theoretical findings.

5 From Theory to Method: Discriminative Regularization

In Section¬†4 we show that once the components of the pretrained model related to the forgetting data are identified and removed, unlearning accuracy can be significantly improved. However, in practice, the training dataset and model are often not well-structured (1 and 2 may not hold). In such cases, as motivated by Equation¬†5, we know that the fine-tuning space may fail to unlearn from the forgetting data, allowing all information from the pretrained model to be retained. This raises the question: what happens if the fine-tuning space learns incorrect or faulty information about the forgetting data? To ensure that fine-tuning not only preserves the utility of the model on remaining data but also effectively forgets the target data, we introduce a regularized constraint on the fine-tuning unlearn process. Specifically, we encourage the model to forget by learning incorrect labels for the target data, which leads the following optimization problem:

KL-FT:minùê∞t‚Å°‚ÑíCE‚Å¢(ùê∞t;ùêó,ùêò)‚èüfor retain accuracy+Œ±‚Å¢‚ÑíKL‚Å¢(ùê∞t;ùêóf,ùêòf‚Ä≤)‚èüregularization for forget accuracy,KL-FT:subscriptsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscript‚èüsubscript‚ÑíCEsubscriptùê∞ùë°ùêóùêòfor retain accuracysubscript‚èüùõºsubscript‚ÑíKLsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêóùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùêòùëì‚Ä≤regularization for forget accuracy\text{KL-FT:}\quad\min_{\mathbf{w}_{t}}\underbrace{\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}(% \mathbf{w}_{t};\mathbf{X},\mathbf{Y})}_{\text{for retain accuracy}}+% \underbrace{\alpha{\mathcal{L}_{\text{KL}}}(\mathbf{w}_{t};\mathbf{X}_{f},% \mathbf{Y}_{f}^{\prime})}_{\text{regularization for forget accuracy}},KL-FT: roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under‚èü start_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_X , bold_Y ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT for retain accuracy end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + under‚èü start_ARG italic_Œ± caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT regularization for forget accuracy end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6)

where the first term is the cross entropy loss function used to measure the model‚Äôs accuracy on the remaining dataset; Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is a regularization parameter that balances the trade-off between maintaining accuracy on the remaining data and forgetting the target data; the second term corresponds to the Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence function applied to the target data, which is intentionally mislabeled [8]. This term acts as a penalty, encouraging the model to reduce its ability to accurately predict the target data, thereby facilitating the unlearning process.

Comparisons with prior work. We compare our approach with related work on regularized fine-tuning methods. One recent work [6] similar to ours is based on Saliency-based unlearning by minimizing the following optimization problem:

CE-FT:minùê∞t‚Å°‚ÑíCE‚Å¢(ùê∞t;ùêóf,ùêòf‚Ä≤)‚èüfor unlearning accuracy+Œ±‚Å¢‚ÑíCE‚Å¢(ùê∞t;ùêó,ùêò)‚èüregularization for remaining accuracy.CE-FT:subscriptsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscript‚èüsubscript‚ÑíCEsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêóùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùêòùëì‚Ä≤for unlearning accuracysubscript‚èüùõºsubscript‚ÑíCEsubscriptùê∞ùë°ùêóùêòregularization for remaining accuracy\text{CE-FT:}\quad\min_{\mathbf{w}_{t}}\underbrace{{\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}}(% \mathbf{w}_{t};\mathbf{X}_{f},\mathbf{Y}_{f}^{\prime})}_{\text{for unlearning % accuracy}}+\underbrace{\alpha\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}(\mathbf{w}_{t};\mathbf{X}% ,\mathbf{Y})}_{\text{regularization for remaining accuracy}}.CE-FT: roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under‚èü start_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT for unlearning accuracy end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + under‚èü start_ARG italic_Œ± caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_X , bold_Y ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT regularization for remaining accuracy end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (7)

The primary difference between Equation¬†6 and Equation¬†7 lies in two keys: ùüè)\mathbf{1)}bold_1 ) Type of Loss Functions. Equation¬†6 employs a combination of cross-entropy loss to maintain accuracy and KL-divergence to control forget accuracy, emphasizing aligning the mislabeled model‚Äôs predictions with the target data distribution. In contrast, Equation¬†7 relies exclusively on cross-entropy loss for both retain and forget accuracy, thus focusing more directly on minimizing classification errors. ùüê)\mathbf{2)}bold_2 ) Regularization Focus. Equation¬†6 primarily aims to preserve retaining performance with regularization to penalize distributional differences. On the other hand, Equation¬†7 focuses on enhancing forget accuracy with regularization to retain the remaining accuracy. Notably, the regularization parameter is typically constrained to the range (0,1]01(0,1]( 0 , 1 ].

However, based on our previous analysis, we favor the principle that regularization should prioritize remaining accuracy over unlearning accuracy (since retaining overlapping features does not significantly impact UA, but discarding them compromises RA). Therefore, we will explore the impact of switching the regularization focus in Equation¬†7, which we refer to as Inverse CE (ICE).

6 Experiment

In this section, we verify our theoretical insights by evaluating the effectiveness of the regularization-based FT machine unlearning methods through numerical experiments.

6.1 Experiment Setups

Datasets and Models. The baseline method is the naive fine-tuning approach [8, 30] implemented on ResNet-18 [12] and we also include the golden retrained model for comparison. Our experiments will focus on image classification using the CIFAR-10 [15], CIFAR-100 [15], and SVHN [20] datasets. More details on the experimental setup will be provided in Appendix¬†A.

Evaluation Metrics. We follow the existing work to assess machine unlearning performance from different aspects [8, 10, 28, 17, 24, 33]. Specifically, we focus on the following evaluation metrics:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Unlearning accuracy (UA): We define UA‚Å°(ùê∞t)=1‚àíAccDf‚Å°(ùê∞t)UAsubscriptùê∞ùë°1subscriptAccsubscriptùê∑ùëìsubscriptùê∞ùë°\operatorname{UA}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=1-\operatorname{Acc}_{D_{f}}(\mathbf{w}_{t})roman_UA ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 - roman_Acc start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as [17], measuring how effectively the model has forgotten the targeted data. Here AccDf‚Å°(ùê∞t)subscriptAccsubscriptùê∑ùëìsubscriptùê∞ùë°\operatorname{Acc}_{D_{f}}(\mathbf{w}_{t})roman_Acc start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the accuracy of the unlearned model on the forgetting dataset.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Membership inference attack (MIA) on Dfsubscriptùê∑ùëìD_{f}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (MIA-Efficacy): The efficacy of MIA on the forget dataset, which assesses whether the model still retains any identifiable information about the forgetting data.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Remaining accuracy (RA): The accuracy of the model on the remaining dataset Drsubscriptùê∑ùëüD_{r}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after unlearning, measuring how well the model retains its performance from pretrained model.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Testing accuracy (TA): The accuracy of the model on the independent test dataset, indicating its generalization ability after unlearning.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Run-time efficiency (RTE): RTE evaluates the computational efficiency of the unlearning process, including the run-time cost taken to execute the unlearning procedure.

Note that a smaller performance gap between the unlearned model and the golden retrained model indicates the better performance of approximate unlearning.

6.2 Experiment Results

Performance Comparison among Regularization-Based Fine-Tuning Methods. In Table¬†2, we explore the impact of different regularization terms on the performance of various FT-based methods. It is evident that the regularization term consistently enhances the model‚Äôs unlearning accuracy. Specifically, in the CIFAR-10 experiments, all regularization-based methods show a significant improvement in UA compared to the baseline FT (20.89%percent20.8920.89\%20.89 %). Both ICE-FT and CE-FT achieve perfect performance in UA and MIA-Efficacy, showing no gap with the golden model. However, it is also noticeable that their RA and TA, especially for the CE-FT method, decrease dramatically, indicating that the improvement in UA comes at the expense of reduced RA and TA. Notably, our KL-FT method achieves the most comparable RA of 99.06%percent99.0699.06\%99.06 % and TA of 92.54%percent92.5492.54\%92.54 % relative to the baseline Retrain (100.00%percent100.00100.00\%100.00 % and 94.87%percent94.8794.87\%94.87 %) and FT (99.76%percent99.7699.76\%99.76 % and 93.73%percent93.7393.73\%93.73 %), without the extreme RA decline seen in other methods. Similarly, in the CIFAR-100 experiments, KL-FT achieves the best RA of 99.26%percent99.2699.26\%99.26 % and TA of 73.11%percent73.1173.11\%73.11 %, outperforming all other methods, with only a minor decline in UA. These highlight the effectiveness of KL-FT in balancing unlearning and remaining accuracy. For the SVHN dataset, the FT method shows even more challenges in forgetting classes, with a UA of 17.47%percent17.4717.47\%17.47 %. In contrast, all regularization-based methods, including CE-FT, ICE-FT, KL-FT, achieve perfect UA, signifying complete forgetting. ICE-FT achieves the best TA of 85.56%percent85.5685.56\%85.56 %, closely followed by KL-FT with a TA of 87.54%percent87.5487.54\%87.54 %.

ICE-FT builds upon the CE-FT by adjusting the focus of regularization. Instead of prioritizing forgetting during the unlearning process, ICE-FT balances the two, placing more emphasis on RA. This change allows ICE-FT to achieve perfect unlearning (UA of 100.00%) while maintaining significantly higher RA and TA compared to CE-FT across all datasets. These results align with our previous theoretical analysis, which suggests that focusing on retention does not significantly impact UA, but shifting the focus away from retention compromises RA.

Sensitivity of regularization parameter Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±. The regularization parameter Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is a crucial hyperparameter in our proposed method. To demonstrate its effect, we conduct numerical experiments on the CIFAR-10 dataset, showing how the regularization parameter impacts the unlearning performance of various regularization-based FT methods. We first examine the sensitivity of the KL method across various evaluation metrics within the range of (0,1]01(0,1]( 0 , 1 ]. As shown in Figure¬†4(a), as Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± increases, the RA gradually declines from near-perfect performance ( ‚àº100%similar-toabsentpercent100\sim 100\%‚àº 100 % ) down to ‚àº94%similar-toabsentpercent94\sim 94\%‚àº 94 % at Œ±=0.8ùõº0.8\alpha=0.8italic_Œ± = 0.8, indicating that stronger regularization negatively affects the retention of information. Meanwhile, the Test Accuracy follows the same downward trend as the Remaining Accuracy, dropping from ‚àº94%similar-toabsentpercent94\sim 94\%‚àº 94 % to ‚àº88%similar-toabsentpercent88\sim 88\%‚àº 88 %. Additionally, we explore how different regularization focuses impact unlearning performance. In Figure¬†4(b), we observe that the RA of CE-FT decreases gradually with increasing Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±, and UA rises slightly before stabilizing, the MIA-Efficacy stays consistently high. In contrast, the ICE-FT method prioritizes retaining accuracy on the remaining data, resulting in a higher Retain Accuracy than CE-FT across all Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± values. The UA slightly decreases but remains competitive, while MIA-Efficacy and Test Accuracy follow similar trends to those seen in CE-FT. This suggests that ICE-FT achieves a better balance between unlearning and accuracy retention than standard CE-FT, which aligns with our previous analysis. Finally, we illustrate the RA and TA behavior for all three methods in Figure¬†4(c).

Discriminative Regularization beyond FT-based methods. While our study focuses on the use of discriminative regularization within fine-tuning (FT)-based machine unlearning methods, the potential applications of this approach extend beyond FT. Our discriminative regularization framework, designed to balance unlearning accuracy (UA) and remaining accuracy (RA), can be adapted to other unlearning techniques, including Gradient Ascent, Fisher Forgetting, or Influence Unlearning. The flexibility of our discriminative regularization framework offers potential for improving a wide range of unlearning strategies, which we leave for future exploration.

7 Conclusion

In conclusion, we present the first theoretical analysis of fine-tuning methods for machine unlearning within a linear regression framework. Our analysis, covering two scenarios‚Äîdistinct and overlapping feature sets‚Äîdemonstrates that while fine-tuning can achieve optimal remaining accuracy (RA), it fails to fully unlearn the forgetting dataset. Our analysis on the failure of naive fine-tuning methods stems from the pretrained model‚Äôs retention of forgetting data, and we propose a theoretical approach to mitigate this issue. By introducing a discriminative regularization term, we effectively balance unlearning accuracy and remaining accuracy. Experimental validation on both synthetic and real-world datasets supports our theoretical insights, showing that regularization-based methods significantly improve unlearning performance without compromising retention.

Experimental Results Figure¬†1(c) and Figure¬†1(d) illustrate that the regularized fine-tuning method discussed in Section¬†4 can significantly improve unlearning accuracy while preserving the remaining accuracy. Specifically, both the remaining loss and unlearning loss of ùê∞^tsubscript^ùê∞ùë°\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{t}over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT perfectly match those of the golden model under both distinct and overlapping feature scenarios. Additionally, Figure¬†2 present comparisons of machine unlearning loss for different approaches to handling overlapping features: Figure¬†2(a) retains overlapping features from the pretrained model, demonstrating matching performance between the regularized ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°\mathbf{w}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT model and golden model ùê∞gsubscriptùê∞ùëî\mathbf{w}_{g}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; whereas Figure¬†2(b) discards the overlapping features, resulting in a decline in remaining accuracy. These empirical results align well with our theoretical findings.

A.2 Additional Real-world Experiments

Unlearning Setup The unlearning setup centers on the FT-based procedure. During training, the model is updated using the remaining dataset, while Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence/Cross-entropy loss regularization is applied to the forget dataset to enforce unlearning. The corresponding regularization modifies the model‚Äôs predictions by encouraging it to generate incorrect outputs for the forgetting data. Specifically, KL divergence is computed between the model‚Äôs output and shifted incorrect labels, ensuring the model no longer retains knowledge of the forgetting data. Additionally, cross-entropy loss between the model‚Äôs output and the incorrect labels further supports the unlearning process. Throughout training, the optimizer updates the model based on the combined loss. Our experiments focus on class-wise forgetting, and we run the process 5 times, reporting the mean and standard deviation of the performances.

We summarize the datasets and model configurations in Tab.‚Äâ3.

Visualization of Remaining Data and Forgetting Data Features. The visualization in Figure¬†5 uses t-SNE to project feature representations of the forgetting and remaining data in CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. The red points correspond to forgetting data, and the blue points represent remaining data. This visualization aims to demonstrate that, in class-wise datasets, the unlearning task for a specific class may involve distinct features. In such cases, naive fine-tuning (FT) methods tend to contribute less towards forgetting the class and focus more on retaining features from the pretrained model.

Corollary 1 (Projection Matrix properties).

Proof of Corollary¬†3.

Proof of Corollary¬†3 follows the proof of Corollary¬†1 directly. ‚àé

Now we are ready to go through the proof of Theorem¬†2. Similar to the non-overlapping case, the golden model holds that
